E.g. explaining how mesh smoothing algor: E.g. explaining how mesh smoothing algorithms work is unnecessary, but the blending types of a Mix node do need a mathematical explanation.)
*1.00 -- January 1994:** Blender `in dev: abbr:`*1.00 -- January 1994:* (*1.00 -- January 1994:*)` Blender `-- in development <https://code.blender.org/2013/12/how-blender-started-twenty-years-ago/>`__ at animation studio NeoGeo
*1.23 -- January 1998:** SGI version pub: abbr:`*1.23 -- January 1998:* (*1.23 -- January 1998:*)` SGI version published on the web, IrisGL
*1.30 -- April 1998:** Linux and FreeBSD: abbr:`*1.30 -- April 1998:* (*1.30 -- April 1998:*)` Linux and FreeBSD version, port to OpenGL and X11
*1.4x -- September 1998:** Sun and Linux: abbr:`*1.4x -- September 1998:* (*1.4x -- September 1998:*)` Sun and Linux Alpha version released
*1.60 -- April 1999:** C-key (new featur: abbr:`*1.60 -- April 1999:* (*1.60 -- April 1999:*)` C-key (new features behind a lock, $95), Windows version released
*1.6x -- June 1999:** BeOS and PPC versi: abbr:`*1.6x -- June 1999:* (*1.6x -- June 1999:*)` BeOS and PPC version released
*1.80 -- June 2000:** End of C-key, Blen: abbr:`*1.80 -- June 2000:* (*1.80 -- June 2000:*)` End of C-key, Blender full freeware again
*2.00 -- August 2000:** Interactive 3D a: abbr:`*2.00 -- August 2000:* (*2.00 -- August 2000:*)` Interactive 3D and real-time engine
*2.10 -- December 2000:** New engine, ph: abbr:`*2.10 -- December 2000:* (*2.10 -- December 2000:*)` New engine, physics, and Python
*2.20 -- August 2001:** Character animat: abbr:`*2.20 -- August 2001:* (*2.20 -- August 2001:*)` Character animation system
*2.21 -- October 2001:** Blender Publish: abbr:`*2.21 -- October 2001:* (*2.21 -- October 2001:*)` Blender Publisher launch
*Blender goes Open Source, 1st Blender C: abbr:`*Blender goes Open Source, 1st Blender Conference.* (*Blender goes Open Source, 1st Blender Conference.*)`
3D Viewport virtual reality scene inspec: 3D Viewport virtual reality scene inspection, new volume object type, Cycles adaptive sampling, Cycles viewport denoising, sculpting improvements, and much more
3D creation software such as Blender hav: 3D creation software such as Blender have an added technical complexity and jargon associated with the underlying technologies. Terms like UV maps, materials, shaders, meshes, and :abbr:`"subdivs" ("subdivs")` are the media of the digital artist, and understanding them, even broadly, will help you to use Blender to its best
A forum based discussions on writing and: A forum based discussions on writing and translating documentation. This includes the user manual, wiki, release notes, and code docs
A guide how to add a new language can be: A guide how to add a new language can be found in the :doc:`/about/contribute/translations/add_language`
A mailing list for discussing ideas, and: A mailing list for discussing ideas, and keeping track of progress
A major overhaul of internal rendering c: A major overhaul of internal rendering capabilities
A mask editor was added, along with an i: A mask editor was added, along with an improved motion tracker, OpenColorIO, Cycles improvements, Sequencer improvements, better mesh tools (Inset and Bevel were improved), new keying nodes, sculpt masking, Collada improvements, a new Skin modifier, a new compositing nodes back end, and the fixing of many bugs
A new Blender version is targeted to be: A new Blender version is targeted to be released every 3 months. The actual `-- release cycle <https://wiki.blender.org/wiki/Process/Release_Cycle>`__ for a specific release is longer, and overlaps the previous and next release cycle
A stabilization version, much work behin: A stabilization version, much work behind the scene, normal and displacement mapping improvements
A totally redesigned UI for easier navig: A totally redesigned UI for easier navigation; improved viewport, gizmos, and tools. With Eevee a new physically based real-time render engine was created. The Grease Pencil got a big overhaul and is now a full 2D drawing and animation system. Replacing the old layers, collections are a powerful way to organize objects. Other improvements: Cycles, Modeling, Animation, Import/Export, Dependency Graph
After submitting the diff, you will be a: After submitting the diff, you will be asked to :abbr:`"Create a new Revision" ("Create a new Revision")` before you can add a title and description of your changes
After this, you can actually view the cr: After this, you can actually view the created html files locally following the prompted instruction, such as
All other settings can remain as set by: All other settings can remain as set by default
All you need to do now is run: All you need to do now is run
An overview of the documentation project: An overview of the documentation project
Another version full of improvements: ob: Another version full of improvements: object hooks, curve deforms and curve tapers, particle duplicators and much more
As a last resort you can add comment (wh: As a last resort you can add comment (which is not shown in the HTML page, but useful for other editors)
As a result, unless a term has an eviden: As a result, unless a term has an evident translation, you should preferably use the English one, :abbr:`*putting it in italic* (*putting it in italic*)`. You can then find a translation for it, which you will use from times to times (e.g. to avoid repetitions...). This is also valid in the other way: even when a term has a straightforward translation, do not hesitate to use its English version from times to times, to get the reader used with it
As the original manual changes, the temp: As the original manual changes, the templates will need updating. Note, doing this is not required, as administrator usually update the files for all languages at once. This allows all languages to be on the same version of the manual. However, if you need to update the files yourself, it can be done as follows
Avoid `weasel words <https://en.wikipedi: Avoid `-- weasel words <https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Weasel_word>`__ and being unnecessarily vague, e.g
Avoid adding terms not found in Blender': Avoid adding terms not found in Blender's interface or the manual
Avoid adding videos which rely on voice,: Avoid adding videos which rely on voice, as this is difficult to translate
Avoid documenting changes in Blender bet: Avoid documenting changes in Blender between releases, that is what the release notes are for. We only need to document the current state of Blender
Avoid duplicating documentation; if expl: Avoid duplicating documentation; if explaining the term is the primary focus of another section of the manual (e.g. if the term is the name of a tool), either just link to that section, or avoid creating a glossary entry entirely
Avoid enumerations of similar options, s: Avoid enumerations of similar options, such as listing every preset or every frame rate in a select menu
Avoid heavily wrapped text (i.e. sentenc: Avoid heavily wrapped text (i.e. sentences can have their own lines)
Avoid including specific details such as: Avoid including specific details such as
Avoid overly long entries. If an explana: Avoid overly long entries. If an explanation of a complex term is needed, supplement with external links
Avoid product placements, i.e. unnecessa: Avoid product placements, i.e. unnecessarily promoting software or hardware brands. Keep content vendor-neutral where possible
Avoid repeating the term immediately or: Avoid repeating the term immediately or using it in the definition
Avoid repetition of large portions of te: Avoid repetition of large portions of text. Simply explain it once, and from then on refer to that explanation
Avoid specifying the resolution of the i: Avoid specifying the resolution of the image, so that the theme can handle the images consistently and provide the best layout across different screen sizes
Avoid technical explanations about the m: Avoid technical explanations about the mathematical/algorithmic implementation of a feature if there is a simpler way to explain it
Avoid using constructs such as \"it is\": Avoid using constructs such as :abbr:`"it is" ("it is")` or :abbr:`"xyz is" ("xyz is")` before the definition
Avoid writing in first person perspectiv: Avoid writing in first person perspective, about yourself or your own opinions
Be sure to check the :doc:`/about/contri: Be sure to check the :doc:`/about/contribute/guides/writing_guide` for conventions and :doc:`/about/contribute/guides/markup_guide` to learn how to write in the reStructuredText markup language
Before you make any edits that are not s: Before you make any edits that are not simple and plainly justified (for example, moving folders around), you should verify with a manual maintainer that your contribution is along the community's vision for the manual. This ensures the best use of your time and good will as it is otherwise possible that, for some reason, your changes will conflict and be rejected or need time-consuming review. For example, another person may be already working on the section you wish to change, the section may be scheduled for deletion or to be updated according to a planned change to Blender
Being freely available from the start, e: Being freely available from the start, even while it was closed source, considerably helped Blender's adoption by the community. A large, stable, and active community of users has gathered around Blender since 1998. The community showed its support for Blender in 2002 when they helped raise €100,000 in seven weeks to enable Blender to go Open Source under the `-- GNU GPL License <https://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl.html>`__
Being open source, Blender welcomes deve: Being open source, Blender welcomes development from volunteers. Communication between developers is done mostly through three platforms
Below are listed the installation comman: Below are listed the installation commands for popular Linux distributions
Below examples show the process to creat: Below examples show the process to create a new set of files for French, language code ``fr``, on Linux platform. Other platforms might vary slightly but should be mainly the same
Blender 2.5x -- The Recode: Blender 2.5x -- The Recode! -- Blender 2.5x -- The Recode
Blender can be used to create 3D visuali: Blender can be used to create 3D visualizations such as still images, 3D animations, VFX shots, and video editing
Blender has 23 different kinds of modifi: abbr:`"Blender has 23 different kinds of modifiers." ("Blender has 23 different kinds of modifiers.")`
Blender has a wide variety of tools maki: Blender has a wide variety of tools making it suitable for almost any sort of media production. People and studios around the world use it for hobby projects, commercials, and feature films
Blender is a cross-platform application,: Blender is a cross-platform application, running on Linux, macOS, and Windows systems. Blender also has relatively small memory and drive requirements compared to other 3D creation suites. Its interface uses OpenGL to provide a consistent experience across all supported hardware and platforms
Blender is a fully integrated 3D content: Blender is a fully integrated 3D content creation suite, offering a broad range of essential tools, including :doc:`-- Modeling </modeling/introduction>`, :doc:`-- Rendering </render/introduction>`, :doc:`-- Animation & Rigging </animation/introduction>`, :doc:`-- Video Editing </video_editing/index>`, :doc:`-- VFX </movie_clip/index>`, :doc:`-- Compositing </compositing/introduction>`, :doc:`-- Texturing </editors/uv/introduction>`, and many types of :doc:`-- Simulations </physics/introduction>`
Blender is well suited to individuals an: Blender is well suited to individuals and small studios who benefit from its unified pipeline and responsive development process
Blender itself has a system of module ow: Blender itself has a system of module owners with developer and artist members who are responsible for the design and maintenance of the assigned Blender areas. See the `-- module owners page <https://wiki.blender.org/wiki/Process/Module_Owners/List>`__ for more information
Blender makes it possible to perform a w: Blender makes it possible to perform a wide range of tasks, and it may seem daunting when first trying to grasp the basics. However, with a bit of motivation and the right learning material, it is possible to familiarize yourself with Blender after a few hours of practice
Blender often has 100's of bugs fixed be: Blender often has 100's of bugs fixed between releases, so it is not realistic to reference even a fraction of them from the manual, while keeping this list up to date
Blender's community is one of its greate: Blender's community is one of its greatest features, so apart from this user manual, there are many different ways to get support from other users, such as :ref:`blender-chat` and `-- Stack Exchange <https://blender.stackexchange.com/>`__
Bmesh was merged with the trunk, with fu: Bmesh was merged with the trunk, with full support for n-sided polygons, sculpt hiding, a panoramic camera for Cycles, mirror ball environment textures and float precision textures, render layer mask layers, ambient occlusion and viewport display of background images and render layers. New import and export add-ons were added, and 150 bug fixes
Bring your local repository up to the mo: Bring your local repository up to the most recent version of changes, including the one you have just done
But sometimes that is necessary, for exa: But sometimes that is necessary, for example when talking about the manual itself: To a foreign reader it is not clear, that they can contribute English text only, whereas this is obvious to an English reader
By default, a table of contents should s: By default, a table of contents should show two levels of depth
Can be translated, but only as an additi: Can be translated, but only as an addition, not as a replacement. See also `-- Adding Text`_
Change the current working directory to: Change the current working directory to the directory of ``-- blender_docs``, where the instance of ``Makefile`` resides
Check out the `User Stories page <https:: Check out the `-- User Stories page <https://www.blender.org/features/user-stories/>`__ on the Blender website for more examples
Check out the current translation reposi: Check out the current translation repository using the command
Click *OK* -- the repository will now be: Click :abbr:`*OK* (*OK*)` -- the repository will now be downloaded which may take a few minutes depending on your internet connection
Computer graphics is an incredibly inter: Computer graphics is an incredibly interesting field, there are many rules, exceptions to the rules and interesting details. Expanding into details can add unnecessary content, so keep the text concise and relevant to the topic at hand
Continue with the next step: :doc:`Build: Continue with the next step: :doc:`-- Building </about/contribute/build/linux>`
Continue with the next step: :doc:`-- Building </about/contribute/build/macos>`
Continue with the next step: :doc:`-- Building </about/contribute/build/windows>`
Continue with the next step: :doc:`Editi: Continue with the next step: :doc:`-- Editing </about/contribute/editing>`
Convert all the ``rst`` files into ``pot: Convert all the ``rst`` files into ``pot`` translation files
Converting the RST-files into pretty HTM: Converting the RST-files into pretty HTML pages
Converting the RST-files into pretty HTML pages. There are two ways to run the build process
Create a desktop shortcut to ``make``: Create a desktop shortcut to ``-- make``
Create a patch file by running: Create a patch file by running
Create an entry for the language in the: Create an entry for the language in the html menu by opening file ``./resources/theme/js/version_switch.js`` (assuming you are at the ``-- blender_docs`` subdirectory)
Creating a new set of translation langua: Creating a new set of translation language from English source
Cycles gets basic volumetric support on: Cycles gets basic volumetric support on the CPU, more improvements to the motion tracker, two new modeling modifiers, some UI consistency improvements, and more than 560 bug fixes
Cycles gets improved volumetric support,: Cycles gets improved volumetric support, major upgrade to Grease Pencil, Windows gets Input Method Editors (IMEs) and general improvements to painting, Freestyle, Sequencer and add-ons
Cycles gets volume and SSS support on th: Cycles gets volume and SSS support on the GPU, pie menus are added and tooltips greatly improved, the Intersection modeling tool is added, new Sun Beam node for the Compositor, Freestyle now works with Cycles, texture painting workflow is improved, and more than 220 bug fixes
Cycles support for spherical stereo imag: Cycles support for spherical stereo images for VR, Grease Pencil works more similar to other 2D drawing software, Alembic import and export support, and improvements to Bendy Bones for easier and simpler rigging
Define the term before providing any fur: Define the term before providing any further information
Deformation motion blur and fire/smoke s: Deformation motion blur and fire/smoke support is added to Cycles, UI pop-ups are now draggable. There are performance optimizations for sculpting mode, new interpolation types for animation, many improvements to the GE, and over 400 bug fixes
Despite everything Blender can do, it re: Despite everything Blender can do, it remains a tool. Great artists do not create masterpieces by pressing buttons or manipulating brushes, but by learning and practicing subjects such as human anatomy, composition, lighting, animation principles, etc
Do not embed video tutorials as a means: Do not embed video tutorials as a means of explaining a feature, the writing itself should explain it adequately (though you may include a link to the video at the bottom of the page under the heading ``-- Tutorials``)
Do not forget to always run ``svn update: Do not forget to always run ``-- svn update`` before committing
Do not simply copy the tooltips from Ble: Do not simply copy the tooltips from Blender. -- People will come to the manual to learn :abbr:`*more* (*more*)` than is provided by the UI
Do not translate it! It will do more har: Do not translate it! It will do more harm than good
Do not use animated ``.gif`` files, thes: Do not use animated ``.gif`` files, these are hard to maintain, can be distracting and are usually large in file size. Instead use a video if needed (see `-- Videos`_ below)
Do not use special characters or spaces: Do not use special characters or spaces
Download the `Python installation packag: Download the `-- Python installation package <https://www.python.org/downloads/>`__ for Windows. In this guide version 3.6.x is used
During the setup, some warnings may be s: During the setup, some warnings may be shown, but do not worry about them. However, if any errors occur, they may cause some problems
Dynamic topology, rigid body simulation,: Dynamic topology, rigid body simulation, improvements in UI and usability (including retina display support), Cycles now supports hair, the Bevel tool now supports individual vertex beveling, new :doc:`-- Mesh Cache </modeling/modifiers/modify/mesh_cache>` modifier and the new :doc:`-- UV Warp </modeling/modifiers/modify/uv_warp>` modifier, new SPH particle fluid solver. More than 250 bug fixes
Each Blender version has its own Bcon ph: Each Blender version has its own Bcon phase, indicating which types of changes are allowed to be committed and what writers are focusing on
Each ``.rst`` file should only have one: Each ``.rst`` file should only have one chapter heading (``*``) per file
Enabling previews adds 65536 bytes to th: abbr:`"Enabling previews adds 65536 bytes to the size of each blend-file [unless it is compressed]." ("Enabling previews adds 65536 bytes to the size of each blend-file [unless it is compressed].")`
Ensure the previous instance of ``build`: Ensure the previous instance of ``-- build`` directory is removed, if any exists
Enter the ``blender_docs`` folder which: Enter the ``-- blender_docs`` folder which was just added by the SVN checkout
Enter the entry: ``\"fr\": \"Fran&ccedil: Enter the entry: ``-- "fr": "Français",``, (``-- "fr": "Français"``). (Notice the Unicode characters.)
Even more modeling tools, Cycles improve: Even more modeling tools, Cycles improved in many areas, plane tracking is added to the motion tracker, better support for FBX import/export, and over 270 bugs fixed
Every now and then you may want to make: Every now and then you may want to make sure your dependencies are up to date using
Figures should be used to place images: Figures should be used to place images
Find the table for the languages in ``va: Find the table for the languages in ``var all_langs = {..};``
Fire and smoke improvements, anisotropic: Fire and smoke improvements, anisotropic shader for Cycles, modifier improvements, the Bevel tool now includes rounding, new add-ons, and over 200 bug fixes
First of all, it is assumed that you hav: First of all, it is assumed that you have the manual already building. If you have not done this already go back too the :ref:`-- Getting Started <about-getting-started>` section
Firstly, make sure that your local copy: Firstly, make sure that your local copy of the manual is up to date with the online repository using
Focus should be on fixes and other incre: Focus should be on fixes and other incremental improvements. All new Blender features should be documented by the end of this stage
Focus should be wrapping up fixes and ot: Focus should be wrapping up fixes and other incremental improvements
Following the success of the SIGGRAPH co: Following the success of the SIGGRAPH conference in early 2000, NaN secured financing of €4.5M from venture capitalists. This large inflow of cash enabled NaN to rapidly expand its operations. Soon NaN boasted as many as 50 employees working around the world trying to improve and promote Blender. In the summer of 2000, Blender 2.0 was released. This version of Blender added the integration of a game engine to the 3D application. By the end of 2000, the number of users registered on the NaN website exceeded 250,000
For Linux users, you will have to check: For Linux users, you will have to check with your distribution's software center for a version of Poedit. This editor is only a recommendation. There are others, such as Kate and Kwrite, that could offer syntax highlighting and basic tools for text editing, e.g. letter case transposes. Other platforms can use some text editors supporting the syntax highlighting for PO files, or allowing you to create a custom one (such as Notepad++ on Windows)
For consistency, and since it would be g: For consistency, and since it would be good to ensure screenshots are all a similar size when floated next to text, writers should take screenshots in the following manner
For example, to build only the documenta: For example, to build only the documentation for the modifiers, use ``-- make modifiers``. You can then view this quick build by opening ``build/html/contents_quicky.html``
For general terminology, consider defini: For general terminology, consider defining a ``:term:`` in the :doc:`-- glossary </glossary/index>`
For more on the GPL, check its page on t: For more on the GPL, check its page on the `-- GNU Project website <https://www.gnu.org/licenses/licenses.html#GPL>`__
For naming files use underscores to sepa: For naming files use underscores to separate chapters and sections, and use dashes to separate sections that are two or more words. So for image files should look like: ``chapter_subsection_sub-subsection_id.png``, e.g
For real-time discussion, we have `blend: For real-time discussion, we have `blender.chat <https://blender.chat>`__ which uses `-- Blender ID <https://id.blender.org>`__ for authentication
For the appropriate system, run the comm: For the appropriate system, run the command in a terminal
Freestyle was added, paint system improv: Freestyle was added, paint system improvements, subsurface scattering for Cycles, Ceres library in the motion tracker, new custom Python nodes, new mesh modeling tools, better support for UTF-8 text and improvements in Text editors, new add-ons for 3D printing, over 260 bug fixes
From the ``blender_docs`` directory to g: From the ``-- blender_docs`` directory to generate a set of files for ``fr`` language
From the directory containing your check: From the directory containing your checkout of the manual run
Full rework of armature system, shape ke: Full rework of armature system, shape keys, fur with particles, fluids, and rigid bodies
Game Engine returns, ambient occlusion,: Game Engine returns, ambient occlusion, new procedural textures
Generally, **you should always translate: Generally, :abbr:`*you should always translate exactly what is in the text* (*you should always translate exactly what is in the text*)`, and avoid providing updates or extra information
Get involved in discussions through any: Get involved in discussions through any of the project `-- Contacts`_
Goto ``https://developer.blender.org`` t: Goto ``https://developer.blender.org`` to create an account for yourself and become a developer/translator for the Blender organization
If a term is definitively not translatab: If a term is definitively not translatable, simply use the English one, but make sure its glossary entry is translated
If all goes well, you should see the fol: If all goes well, you should see the following message when it is finished
If the language you want to translate ha: If the language you want to translate has not been started by someone else already and you wish to create a set of new files for the desired language, say 'fr' (French), then you must first use the environment you have created, as guided in :ref:`-- Getting Started <about-getting-started>`, in particular :doc:`/about/contribute/install/index` and :doc:`/about/contribute/build/index` sections
If you are going to add or overhaul a se: If you are going to add or overhaul a section, be sure to check carefully that it does not already exist. In some places, the docs are so disorganized that sections may be duplicated or in a strange location. In the case that you find a duplicate or out of place section, `-- create a task <https://developer.blender.org/maniphest/task/edit/form/default/?project=PHID-PROJ-c4nvvrxuczix2326vlti>`__ explaining the issue, and optionally include a revision (actual changes)
If you are in doubt about functionality: If you are in doubt about functionality that you wish to document, you should pose your questions to the Blender developers responsible for that area or ask at the unofficial user support channel in the ``#docs`` or ``#blender-coders`` channel in :ref:`blender-chat`
If you are interested in helping develop: If you are interested in helping develop Blender, see the `-- Get Involved <https://www.blender.org/get-involved/>`__ page
If you are on Windows and do not have ``: If you are on Windows and do not have ``-- make``, run
If you are unsure about how a feature wo: If you are unsure about how a feature works, ask someone else or find out who developed it and ask them
If you are working on a specific chapter: If you are working on a specific chapter of the manual, you can build it quickly using
If you encounter an error ending with ``: If you encounter an error ending with ``-- TypeError: an integer is required (got type str)``, you may need to install an older version of *Babel* (the Python Internationalization Library)
If you find an error in the documentatio: If you find an error in the documentation, please `-- report the problem <https://developer.blender.org/maniphest/task/edit/form/default/?project=PHID-PROJ-c4nvvrxuczix2326vlti>`__
If you have created or deleted files, yo: If you have created or deleted files, you will need to run ``-- svn add /path/to/file`` or ``-- svn rm /path/to/file`` before creating the diff. To see a list of affected files, run ``-- svn status``
If you leave out ``-m \"message\"``, you: If you leave out ``-- -m "message"``, you will be prompted to type the message in a text editor
If you modify the code and distribute th: If you modify the code and distribute the modified version, you must license your modifications available under the GPL (or a compatible license)
If your patch includes changes to or add: If your patch includes changes to or additional images, simply attach them when you are creating the revision
In 1988, Ton Roosendaal co-founded the D: In 1988, Ton Roosendaal co-founded the Dutch animation studio NeoGeo. NeoGeo quickly became the largest 3D animation studio in the Netherlands and one of the leading animation houses in Europe. NeoGeo created award-winning productions (European Corporate Video Awards 1993 and 1995) for large corporate clients such as the multinational electronics company Philips. Within NeoGeo, Ton was responsible for both art direction and internal software development. After careful deliberation, Ton decided that the current in-house 3D tool set for NeoGeo was too old and cumbersome to maintain, and needed to be rewritten from scratch. In 1995 this rewrite began and was destined to become the 3D software creation we all know as Blender. As NeoGeo continued to refine and improve Blender, it became apparent to Ton that Blender could be used as a tool for other artists outside of NeoGeo
In 1998, Ton decided to found a new comp: In 1998, Ton decided to found a new company called Not a Number (NaN) as a spin-off of NeoGeo to further market and develop Blender. At the core of NaN was a desire to create and distribute a compact, cross-platform 3D application for free. At the time, this was a revolutionary concept as most commercial 3D applications cost thousands of dollars. NaN hoped to bring professional level 3D modeling and animation tools within the reach of the general computing public. NaN's business model involved providing commercial products and services around Blender. In 1999 NaN attended its first SIGGRAPH conference in an effort to more widely promote Blender. Blender's first SIGGRAPH convention was a huge success and gathered a tremendous amount of interest from both the press and attendees. Blender was a hit and its huge potential confirmed
In case a major error is found in the ma: In case a major error is found in the manual the patch will be committed to the release branch
In general, the technical terms used in: In general, the technical terms used in computer graphics are quite new or even downright neologisms invented for the needs, so they do not always have a translation in your language. Moreover, a large part of Blender users use its English interface
In order to maintain a consistent writin: In order to maintain a consistent writing style within the manual, please keep this page in mind and only deviate from it when you have a good reason to do so
In order to submit a patch, follow this: In order to submit a patch, follow this process
In return for these rights, you have som: In return for these rights, you have some responsibilities if you distribute a GPL'd program. These responsibilities are designed to protect your freedoms and the freedoms of others
In some cases you will want to leave a s: In some cases you will want to leave a small margin around the thing you are trying to capture. This should be around 30px but does not have to be exact
In the *Checkout directory* field, enter: In the :abbr:`*Checkout directory* (*Checkout directory*)` field, enter: ``-- C:\blender_docs``
In the *URL of repository* field, enter:: In the :abbr:`*URL of repository* (*URL of repository*)` field, enter: ``-- https://svn.blender.org/svnroot/bf-manual/trunk/blender_docs``
In the glossary, the English term is wri: In the glossary, the English term is written first (to maintain alphabetic order) with the translated entry following in parenthesis, when appropriate
In these (rare) cases you can and should: In these (rare) cases you can and should provide extra information
In this guide, we will use TortoiseSVN t: In this guide, we will use TortoiseSVN though any Subversion client will do
Including why or how an option might be: Including why or how an option might be useful is a good idea
Increase the ``dev`` version in ``resour: Increase the ``-- dev`` version in ``resources/versions.json`` and add the former version as a past release
Inside that folder is a file called ``re: Inside that folder is a file called ``requirements.txt`` which contains a list of all the dependencies we need. Install all the dependencies using Python's ``pip`` command
Inside that folder is a file called ``requirements.txt`` which contains a list of all the dependencies we need. To install these dependencies, we can use the ``pip3`` command
Inside that folder is a file called ``requirements.txt`` which contains a list of all the dependencies we need. To install these dependencies, we can use the ``pip`` command
Install Python with the installation wiz: Install Python with the installation wizard. Please make sure that you enable the :abbr:`"Add Python to PATH" ("Add Python to PATH")` option
Install TortoiseSVN with the installatio: Install TortoiseSVN with the installation wizard. When choosing which features will be installed, it is recommended that you enable :abbr:`*command line client tools* (*command line client tools*)` to give you access to SVN from the command line (there is no harm in doing this, and it may be helpful if you ever run into any trouble)
Install those packages or make sure you: Install those packages or make sure you have them in your system
Instead of creating a patch file, commit: Instead of creating a patch file, committing will submit the change directly to our central repository
Instructions on this page are based on `: Instructions on this page are based on `-- Sphinx Intl documentation <http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/intl.html>`__
Integrated stereo/multi-view pipeline, S: Integrated stereo/multi-view pipeline, Smooth Corrective modifier and new developmental dependency graph
Internationalization of the UI, improvem: Internationalization of the UI, improvements in the animation system and the GE, vertex weight groups modifiers, 3D audio and video, and bug fixes
Issues which are known to the developers: Issues which are known to the developers and are not going to be resolved before the next release can be documented as :abbr:`*Known Limitations* (*Known Limitations*)`. In some cases, it may be best to include them in the :doc:`-- troubleshooting </troubleshooting/index>` section
It boasts active community support, see: It boasts active community support, see `-- blender.org/community <https://www.blender.org/community>`__ for an extensive list of sites
It has a high-quality 3D architecture, e: It has a high-quality 3D architecture, enabling fast and efficient creation workflow
It has a small executable, which is opti: It has a small executable, which is optionally portable
It is best to avoid moving/renaming file: It is best to avoid moving/renaming files as this breaks URLs and without this script translators will lose all their work in these files. Please ask an administrator if you think something should be renamed/moved
It is cross platform, with an OpenGL GUI: It is cross platform, with an OpenGL GUI that is uniform on all major platforms (and customizable with Python scripts)
It is important that the manual can be m: It is important that the manual can be maintained long term, UI and tool options change so try to avoid having a lot of images (when they are not especially necessary). Otherwise, this becomes too much of a maintenance burden
It is recommended you make two environme: It is recommended you make two environment variables for these directories, in the ``.bashrc`` to make it more convenient for changing or scripting batch/shell commands for the process of translation and reviewing results
Keep in mind that Blender has frequent r: Keep in mind that Blender has frequent releases, so try to write content that will not have to be redone the moment some small change is made. This also helps a small documentation community to maintain the manual
Keep sentences short and clear, resultin: Keep sentences short and clear, resulting in text that is easy to read, objective and to the point
Lines should be less than 120 characters: Lines should be less than 120 characters long
Linking to a title in the same file: Linking to a title in the same file
Links to reference and user documentatio: Links to reference and user documentation
Login the account and create a task with: Login the account and create a task with ``-- todo`` type, addressing an administrator in the :abbr:`*Subscribers* (*Subscribers*)` field, requesting for a committer right in order to transfer changes to the central repository of the translation team
Lots of fixes, and some Game Engine feat: Lots of fixes, and some Game Engine features
Lower case filenames underscore between: Lower case filenames underscore between words
Make any changes that you want: Make any changes that you want
Manage tasks such as bugs, todo lists, a: Manage tasks such as bugs, todo lists, and future plans
More details about support can be found: More details about support can be found on the `-- support page <https://www.blender.org/support/>`__
Most people do not use this option becau: abbr:`"Most people do not use this option because ..." ("Most people do not use this option because ...")`
Multiresolution meshes, multi-layer UV t: Multiresolution meshes, multi-layer UV textures, multi-layer images and multi-pass rendering and baking, sculpting, retopology, multiple additional mattes, distort and filter nodes, modeling and animation improvements, better painting with multiple brushes, fluid particles, proxy objects, Sequencer rewrite, and post-production UV texturing
New Cycles features: Denoising, Shadow c: New Cycles features: Denoising, Shadow catcher, and new Principled shader. Other improvements were made to Grease Pencil and Alembic. Support was also added for application templates
New and improved modeling tools, three n: New and improved modeling tools, three new Cycles nodes, big improvements in the motion tracker, Python scripts and drivers are disabled by default when loading files for security reasons, and over 280 bug fixes
Newly generated files will contain some: Newly generated files will contain some placeholders for authors and revision dates etc. If you find the job of replacing them repetitive, make use of the script ``change_placeholders.sh`` in the subdirectory ``-- ~/blender_docs/toos_maintenance``, make a copy of that to your local ``bin`` directory and replace all values that were mentioned in the file with your specific details, then after each change to a file, you would do following commands to update the file with your personal details, revision date and time, plus generating the html files for your language, which you can view using your Internet browser
Node-based textures, armature sketching: Node-based textures, armature sketching (called Etch-a-Ton), Boolean mesh operation improvements, JPEG2000 support, projection painting for direct transfer of images to models, and a significant Python script catalog. GE enhancements included video textures, where you can play movies in-game, upgrades to the Bullet physics engine, dome (fisheye) rendering, and more API GE calls made available
Now that you are able to build the manua: Now that you are able to build the manual, the next paragraph is about an optional quick build
Now you can build the manual with the tr: Now you can build the manual with the translation applied
Now you can edit the PO translation file: Now you can edit the PO translation files, e.g
Now you will have a build of the manual: Now you will have a build of the manual with translations applied
On this page French (``fr``) is used for: On this page French (``fr``) is used for examples. However, it can be replaced with other `-- languages codes <https://www.gnu.org/software/gettext/manual/html_node/Usual-Language-Codes.html>`__. So, be sure to change the ``/fr`` suffixes in this guide to the language you are translating
Once the docs have been built, all the H: Once the docs have been built, all the HTML files can be found inside ``-- C:\blender_docs\build\html``"html``. Try opening ``" ("html``. Try opening ``")`build\html\index.html`` in your web browser and read the manual
Once the docs have been built, all the HTML files can be found inside ``-- ~/blender_docs/build/html``. Try opening ``build/html/index.html`` in your web browser and read the manual
Once the installation has finished, crea: Once the installation has finished, create a new folder that will contain everything related to the Blender Manual. In this guide, we will use ``-- C:\blender_docs``
One of the largest community forums is `: One of the largest community forums is `-- Blender Artists <http://blenderartists.org/forum/>`__, where Blender users gather to show off their creations, get feedback, ask and offer help and, in general, discuss Blender
Only translate these, when the localized: Only translate these, when the localized expression is common! See also `-- Technical Terms`_
Open a Command Prompt. (Run as Administr: Open a Command Prompt. (Run as Administrator)

Open an instance of the console applicat: Open an instance of the console application, such as Gnome-Terminal emulator
Open the new folder, right-click and cho: Open the new folder, right-click and choose :abbr:`*SVN Checkout...* (*SVN Checkout...*)` from the context menu
OpenVDB support for caching of smoke/vol: OpenVDB support for caching of smoke/volumetric simulations, improved Cycles subsurface scattering, Grease Pencil stroke sculpting and improved workflow, and reworked library handling to manage missing and deleted data-blocks
Or open a command prompt and change to t: Or open a command prompt and change to the repository with ``cd C:\blender_docs``
Order naming with specific identifiers a: Order naming with specific identifiers at the end
Otherwise you will get a warning: ``'loc: Otherwise you will get a warning: ``-- 'locale' is not under version control``
Particle interactions, LSCM UV mapping,: Particle interactions, LSCM UV mapping, functional YafRay integration, weighted creases in subdivision surfaces, ramp shaders, full OSA, and many (many) more
Parts* should only be used for contents: abbr:`*Parts* (*Parts*)` should only be used for contents or index pages
Perform ``make`` command to turn transla: Perform ``-- make`` command to turn translated texts in po files into html files for testing locally
Pixar OpenSubdiv support, Viewport and F: Pixar OpenSubdiv support, Viewport and File Browser performance boost, node auto-offset, and a text effect strip for the Sequencer
Place the image in the ``manual/images``: Place the image in the ``-- manual/images`` folder. Use no other subfolders
Please check if the Documentation projec: Please check if the Documentation project is assigned in the tag's field in order to notify the team of your patch. You can also :ref:`-- contact <contribute-contact>` the team over the mailing list or :ref:`blender-chat`
Prepare the area you would like to captu: Prepare the area you would like to capture making sure to use the default theme and setting. (In some cases you may not want to use the default settings e.g. if some options are hidden behind a checkbox.)
Preview release of the 2.3x UI makeover: Preview release of the 2.3x UI makeover presented at the 2nd Blender Conference
RST-files can then be freely moved and t: RST-files can then be freely moved and the remap script will move the locale file after
Reloading the file will probably fix the: abbr:`"Reloading the file will probably fix the problem" ("Reloading the file will probably fix the problem")`
Revamped sculpting tools, Cycles OptiX a: Revamped sculpting tools, Cycles OptiX accelerated rendering, denoising, many Eevee improvements, library overrides, UI improvements and much more
Save this file as ``conf.py`` in the ``b: Save this file as ``conf.py`` in the ``-- blender_docs`` directory, where ``Makefile`` resides
Sections should be generally structured: Sections should be generally structured as follows
See the `overview on ReStructuredText <h: See the `-- overview on ReStructuredText <http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/rest.html>`__ for more information on how to style the various elements of the documentation and on how to add lists, tables, pictures and code blocks. The `-- Sphinx reference <http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/markup/>`__ provides more insight additional constructs
Serious bug fixes, with some performance: Serious bug fixes, with some performance issues addressed
Should I Translate: Should I Translate\.\.\. ? -- Should I Translate
Simply check out the Blender Manual's re: Simply check out the Blender Manual's repository using
Simply mark the text as fuzzy and/or add: Simply mark the text as fuzzy and/or add a comment. The next translator might understand it
So keep reading this manual, learn the g: So keep reading this manual, learn the great tool that Blender is, keep your mind open to other artistic and technological areas and you too can become a great artist
Straightforward patches are bound to be: Straightforward patches are bound to be accepted very quickly. Once you get accustomed to making changes and no longer need feedback, we cut out the middle man and give you direct access to edit the manual
Submit new set of files to the central r: Submit new set of files to the central repository
Support for custom normals, viewport com: Support for custom normals, viewport compositing and improvements to hair dynamics
Take care about grammar, appropriate wor: Take care about grammar, appropriate wording and use simple English
Tells ``svn`` to ignore this file when p: Tells ``svn`` to ignore this file when performing operations by executing this shell command
That means for example that Blender 2.90: That means for example that Blender 2.90 can be in Bcon3 (wrapping up), while Blender 2.91 is in Bcon1 (new features and changes)
The Apricot release, cool GLSL shaders,: The Apricot release, cool GLSL shaders, lights and GE improvements, snap, sky simulator, Shrinkwrap modifier, and Python editing improvements. This contained the results `-- Project Apricot <https://apricot.blender.org/>`__
The Blender Foundation's primary goal wa: The Blender Foundation's primary goal was to find a way to continue developing and promoting Blender as a community-based `-- open source <https://opensource.org/>`__ project. In July 2002, Ton managed to get the NaN investors to agree to a unique Blender Foundation plan to attempt to release Blender as open source. The :abbr:`"Free Blender" ("Free Blender")` campaign sought to raise €100,000 so that the Foundation could buy the rights to the Blender source code and intellectual property rights from the NaN investors and subsequently release Blender to the open source community. With an enthusiastic group of volunteers, among them several ex-NaN employees, a fundraising campaign was launched to :abbr:`"Free Blender" ("Free Blender")`. To everyone's surprise and delight the campaign reached the €100,000 goal in only seven short weeks. On Sunday, October 13, 2002, Blender was released to the world under the terms of the `-- GNU GPL <https://www.gnu.org/copyleft/gpl>`__. Blender development continues to this day, driven by a team of dedicated volunteers from around the world led by Blender's original creator, Ton Roosendaal
The Blender Manual is a community driven: The Blender Manual is a community driven effort to which anyone can contribute. Whether you like to fix a tiny spelling mistake or rewrite an entire chapter, your help with the Blender manual is most welcome
The Cycles renderer was added to the tru: The Cycles renderer was added to the trunk, the camera tracker was added, dynamic paint for modifying textures with mesh contact/approximation, the Ocean modifier to simulate ocean and foam, new add-ons, bug fixes, and more extensions added for the Python API
The GPL only applies to the Blender appl: The GPL only applies to the Blender application and :abbr:`*not* (*not*)` the artwork you create with it; for more info see the `-- Blender License <https://www.blender.org/about/license/>`__
The Peach release was the result of a hu: The Peach release was the result of a huge effort of over 70 developers providing enhancements to provide hair and fur, a new particle system, enhanced image browsing, cloth, a seamless and non-intrusive physics cache, rendering improvements in reflections, AO, and render baking, a Mesh Deform modifier for muscles and such, better animation support via armature tools and drawing, skinning, constraints and a colorful Action Editor, and much more. It contained the results of `-- Project Peach <https://peach.blender.org/>`__
The `-- Carve library <https://code.google.com/archive/p/carve/>`__ was added to improve Boolean operations, support for object tracking was added, the Remesh modifier was added, many improvements in the GE, matrices and vectors in the Python API were improved, plus new add-ons, and many bug fixes
The ``ID`` is found in the video's URL,: The ``ID`` is found in the video's URL, e.g
The ``blender-v{VERSION}-release`` branc: The ``-- blender-v{VERSION}-release`` branch will be available for 5 weeks prior to the release date. At the same time ``-- master`` will be open for the next release, giving 2 months to add documentation for new features of the next release, and another month to make improvements
The big news, in addition to two new mod: The big news, in addition to two new modifiers and re-awakening the 64-bit OS support, was the addition of subsurface scattering, which simulates light scattering beneath the surface of organic and soft objects
The building process is different for ea: The building process is different for each operating system, instructions have been written for
The building process may take several mi: The building process may take several minutes the first time (or after any major changes), but the next time you build it should only take a few seconds
The first 5 weeks overlap with the Bcon3: The first 5 weeks overlap with the Bcon3 and Bcon4 phases of the previous release, Writing focus will be split on fixes for the previous release and writing documentation for features already added or likely to be added to Blender. This is also the perfect time to make any larger or more disruptive improvements to the manual
The first few times you make changes to: The first few times you make changes to the manual, you will need to submit them as patches for an administrator to review. This is just to make sure that we maintain a quality user manual, and that you do not accidentally break anything vital before you get used to the system
The first truly open source Blender rele: The first truly open source Blender release
The following are useful markups for tex: The following are useful markups for text styling
The following guides lead you through th: The following guides lead you through the process
The idea is to enclose all the content o: The idea is to enclose all the content of a section inside of a folder. Ideally every section should have an ``index.rst`` (containing the TOC for that section) and an ``introduction.rst`` (introducing) to the contents of the section
The main goals for this manual are as fo: The main goals for this manual are as follows
The manual is archived on the server and: The manual is archived on the server and redirects / symlinks are updated. See the :ref:`-- Release Guide <about-contribute-guides-release>` for more information
The manual is written for people educate: The manual is written for people educated in computer graphics, who understand the basics of 3D and/or know other 3D software. While some areas of computer graphics are highly technical, this manual shall be kept understandable by non-technical users
The manual is written in the `reStructur: The manual is written in the `-- reStructuredText <http://www.sphinx-doc.org/en/stable/rest.html>`__ (RST) markup language and can be edited using a plain text editor. For a local preview, you convert (build) the manual source files from RST into HTML web pages
The manual provides detailed functional: The manual provides detailed functional description of all features, tools and options in Blender. While there is a canonical source of truth for each of Blender's key areas, this does not mean we have to document every small detail. The manual should provide information on what a feature is, how to use it, and its purpose. More background information should be provided when necessary to give deeper understanding of a 3D pipeline
The modified ``.po`` files can be edited: The modified ``.po`` files can be edited and committed back to svn
The nodes release, Array modifier, vecto: The nodes release, Array modifier, vector blur, new physics engine, rendering, lip sync, and many other features. This was the release following `-- Project Orange <https://orange.blender.org/>`__
The option must be enabled so you can bu: The option must be enabled so you can build the manual with the make script
The repository will now be downloaded wh: The repository will now be downloaded which may take a few minutes depending on your internet connection
The second open source Blender release: The second open source Blender release
The translations are licensed under the: The translations are licensed under the same :doc:`/copyright` as the original
The updated templates can then be commit: The updated templates can then be committed to svn
Their contents may be summarized or simp: Their contents may be summarized or simply omitted. -- Such lists are only showing what is already :abbr:`*obvious* (*obvious*)` in the interface and end up being a lot of text to read and maintain
Then you will be asked for your user nam: Then you will be asked for your user name (from ``developer.blender.org``) and password before the change is committed
There are `several independent websites: There are `-- several independent websites <https://www.blender.org/support/user-community/>`__ such as forums, blogs, news, and tutorial sites dedicated to Blender
There are also more official sources of: There are also more official sources of support, such as `-- Certified Trainers <https://www.blender.org/certification/>`__ and the `-- Blender Cloud <https://cloud.blender.org/>`__. If you think you have found an issue with Blender, you can easily `-- report a bug <https://developer.blender.org/maniphest/task/edit/form/1/>`__
There is support for syntax highlighting: There is support for syntax highlighting if the programming language is provided, and line numbers can be optionally shown with the ``:linenos:`` option
These details are not useful for users t: These details are not useful for users to memorize and they become quickly outdated
These files are still in English only, w: These files are still in English only, with all ``msgstr`` entries blank
They will review your patch and let you: They will review your patch and let you know about any changes you could make, or commit the patch if it is accepted
This can be applied to several parts of: This can be applied to several parts of the interface but might not work for all cases
This creates a simple text file that sho: This creates a simple text file that shows what text was added, removed or changed between your working files and the central repository
This guide covers the following topics: This guide covers the following topics
This guide relies heavily on command-lin: This guide relies heavily on command-line tools. It assumes you are the least familiar with the macOS Terminal application
This is optional, translations are autom: This is optional, translations are automatically built online, e.g: https://docs.blender.org/manual/fr/dev
This is the command you will always use: This is the command you will always use when building the docs. The building process may take several minutes the first time (or after any major changes), but the next time you build it should only take a few seconds
This manual is a good start, though it s: This manual is a good start, though it serves more as a reference. There are also many online video tutorials from specialized websites
This page covers conventions concerning: This page covers conventions concerning the translations
This page covers the conventions for wri: This page covers the conventions for writing and use of the reStructuredText (RST) markup syntax
This page provides a list of changes tha: This page provides a list of changes that need to be made to the manual. This is a great place for new contributors to start but also check the `-- documentation workboard <https://developer.blender.org/project/board/53/>`__
This script also works for image file na: This script also works for image file names
This section documents how to install th: This section documents how to install the software used to generate the manual. The installation is different for each operating system, instructions have been written for
This section is specifically about the :: This section is specifically about the :doc:`-- Glossary </glossary/index>` section, where we define common terms in Blender and computer graphics
This series released four `pre-version <: This series released four `-- pre-version <https://archive.blender.org/development/release-logs/blender-256-beta>`__ (from Alpha 0 in November 2009 to Beta in July 2010) and three stable versions (from 2.57 - April 2011 to 2.59 - August 2011). It was one of the most important development projects, with a total refactor of the software with new functions, redesign of the internal window manager and event/tool/data handling system, and new Python API. The final version of this project was Blender 2.59 in August 2011
This will build very quickly, but it wil: This will build very quickly, but it will mean your next complete build of all the chapters will be slow
This will create a ``locale/fr`` subdire: This will create a ``-- locale/fr`` subdirectory
This will download all language sets ava: This will download all language sets available in the repository into the ``-- locale`` directory of your drive. You can go to the ``-- locale`` directory to see the hidden subdirectory ``.svn`` within it, together with directories of languages. You'll need to add your own set of files for the language you're trying to translating to
This will give you a foundation environm: This will give you a foundation environment for
This will only give a quick summary howe: This will only give a quick summary however, you can get more information by running

To learn more about reStructuredText, se: To learn more about reStructuredText, see
To link to a specific section in another: To link to a specific section in another document (or the same one), explicit labels are available
To make edit the PO files you will need: To make edit the PO files you will need to install a PO editor. We recommended that you use `Poedit <https://poedit.net/>`__ however, any PO editor will do
To see which languages are currently ava: To see which languages are currently available, you can browse the repository: https://developer.blender.org/diffusion/BMT/browse/trunk/blender_docs/locale
To view your changes, build the manual :: To view your changes, build the manual :doc:`-- as instructed </about/contribute/build/index>`. Keep in mind that you can also build only the chapter you just edited to view it quickly. Open the generated ``.html`` files inside the ``-- build/html`` folder using your web browser, or refresh the page if you have it open already
Transformation tools and widgets, soft b: Transformation tools and widgets, soft bodies, force fields, deflections, incremental subdivision surfaces, transparent shadows, and multi-threaded rendering
UDIM and USD support, Mantaflow for flui: UDIM and USD support, Mantaflow for fluids and smoke simulation, AI denoising, Grease Pencil improvements, and much more
URL references are to be added at the en: URL references are to be added at the end, formatted as follows, e.g
Unfortunately, NaN's ambitions and oppor: Unfortunately, NaN's ambitions and opportunities did not match the company's capabilities and the market realities of the time. This over-extension resulted in restarting NaN with new investor funding and a smaller company in April 2001. Six months later NaN's first commercial software product, Blender Publisher was launched. This product was targeted at the emerging market of interactive web-based 3D media. Due to disappointing sales and the ongoing difficult economic climate, the new investors decided to shut down all NaN operations. The shutdown also included discontinuing the development of Blender. Although there were clearly shortcomings in the then current version of Blender, such as a complex internal software architecture, unfinished features and a non-standard way of providing the GUI, the enthusiastic support from the user community and customers who had purchased Blender Publisher in the past, meant that Ton could not justify leaving Blender to fade into insignificance. Since restarting a company with a sufficiently large team of developers was not feasible, Ton Roosendaal founded the non-profit organization, Blender Foundation, in March 2002
Unless the unit a value is measured in i: Unless the unit a value is measured in is obscure and unpredictable, there is no need to mention it
Update ``resources/versions.json`` for t: Update ``resources/versions.json`` for the future release :abbr:`*before* (*before*)` building an archive version so that the 404 page gets a static version
Update changes in English texts which ha: Update changes in English texts which have been added by other contributors
Use American English (e.g: modeling and: Use American English (e.g: modeling and not modelling, color and not colour) also for formatting numbers (e.g: 2,718.28 and not 2 718,28)
Use ``.png`` for images that have solid: Use ``.png`` for images that have solid colors such as screenshots of the Blender interface, and ``.jpg`` for images with a high amount of color variance, such as sample renders and photographs
Videos from YouTube\\ :sup:`™` can be em: Videos from YouTube\ :sup:`™` can be embedded using
We expect our readers to use the English: We expect our readers to use the English UI
We expect our readers to use the English version of Blender, not a translated one
We will download this new set of languag: We will download this new set of language as guided in the next section
Welcome to Blender, the free and open so: Welcome to Blender, the free and open source 3D creation suite
When RST-files are added or removed the: When RST-files are added or removed the corresponding locale files are added or removed automatically by the update script. However, if files need to be moved please use this Python script
When a program is licensed under the GNU: When a program is licensed under the GNU General Public License (the GPL)
When documenting a panel or section of t: When documenting a panel or section of the UI, it is better to use a single image that shows all of the relevant areas (rather than multiple images for each icon or button) placed at the top of the section you are writing, and then explain the features in the order that they appear in the image
When one hears about \"free software\",: When one hears about :abbr:`"free software" ("free software")`, the first thing that comes to mind might be :abbr:`"no cost" ("no cost")`. While this is often true, the term :abbr:`"free software" ("free software")` as used by the Free Software Foundation (originators of the GNU Project and creators of the GNU General Public License) is intended to mean :abbr:`"free as in freedom" ("free as in freedom")` rather than in the sense of :abbr:`"no cost" ("no cost")` (which is usually referred to as :abbr:`"free as in free beer" ("free as in free beer")` or :abbr:`*gratis* (*gratis*)`). Free software in this sense is software which you are free to use, copy, modify, redistribute, with no limit. Contrast this with the licensing of most commercial software packages, where you are allowed to load the software on a single computer, are allowed to make no copies, and never see the source code. Free software allows incredible freedom to the end user. Since the source code is universally available, there are also many more chances for bugs to be caught and fixed
When running subversion from the command: When running subversion from the command line (such as updating or committing), you will need to change directory to ``-- locale/fr`` first
When the manual is updated, those transl: When the manual is updated, those translations which are outdated will be marked as fuzzy. To keep track with that, you can use a tool we created for that task

When the manual is updated, those translations which are outdated will be marked as fuzzy. To keep track with that, you can use a tool we created for that task, see :ref:`-- How to install it <translations-fuzzy-strings>`
When you are happy with your changes, yo: When you are happy with your changes, you can upload them, so that they will be in the online manual. At first, this is done by submitting patches so that someone can review your changes and give you feedback. After, you can commit your changes directly. This process is described in detail in the next section
Who uses Blender: Who uses Blender? -- Who uses Blender
Work is done in two branches: Work is done in two branches
Work to improve, optimize and fix bugs i: Work to improve, optimize and fix bugs in new and existing features. All big or disruptive changes must be finished at the end of this stage
Would be written like this instead, putt: Would be written like this instead, putting a definition first
Would be written more like this, avoidin: Would be written more like this, avoiding the :abbr:`"it is" ("it is")`
Would be written more like this, avoiding the immediate repetition of the term
You can do this by running: You can do this by running
You can download the latest version of B: You can download the latest version of Blender `-- here <https://www.blender.org/download/>`__
You can link to another document in the: You can link to another document in the manual with
You can modify the manual by editing loc: You can modify the manual by editing local text files. These files are kept in sync with those online via a repository, based on this the server will update the online manual
You can now edit the documentation files: You can now edit the documentation files, which are the ``.rst`` files inside the ``-- manual`` folder using a text editor of your choice
You don't need all other languages being: You don't need all other languages being there, so remove the locale directory for the time being
You have the right to copy and distribut: You have the right to copy and distribute the program
You have the right to improve the progra: You have the right to improve the program, and release your own versions
You have the right to modify the program: You have the right to modify the program and have access to the source codes
You have the right to use the program fo: You have the right to use the program for any purpose
You may not restrict the licensing of th: You may not restrict the licensing of the program beyond the terms of the GPL (you may not turn a GPL'd program into a proprietary product)
You must include the source code or make: You must include the source code or make the source code freely available
You must provide a copy of the GPL with: You must provide a copy of the GPL with the program, so that recipients are aware of their rights under the license
You probably will not find the original: You probably will not find the original scene if it is a screenshot of a file and it is too much load on the server (and too much work for you)
You should get a list of all the files w: You should get a list of all the files with information about the number of empty and fuzzy strings. For more options see
You should have a directory layout like: You should have a directory layout like this
Your modified files are uploaded to the: Your modified files are uploaded to the central repository for others to work with and continue collaborating. Commits are tracked in the repositories `-- Diffusion <https://developer.blender.org/diffusion/BM/>`__. Soon after your changes become visible in the online manual
Zoom out eight zoom levels (:kbd:`Numpad: Zoom out eight zoom levels (:kbd:`Dấu Trừ (-) Bàn Số (NumpadMinus)` -- eight times)
Zoom to the maximum zoom level (hold :kb: Zoom to the maximum zoom level (hold :kbd:`Dấu Cộng (+) Bàn Số (NumpadPlus)` or :kbd:`Ctrl-NCG (MMB)` or similar)
`#blender-coders <https://blender.chat/c: `#blender-coders <https://blender.chat/channel/blender-coders>`__ For developers to discuss Blender development
`#docs <https://blender.chat/channel/doc: `#docs <https://blender.chat/channel/docs>`__ For discussion related to Blender's documentation
`#python <https://blender.chat/channel/t: `#python <https://blender.chat/channel/today>`__ For support for developers using the Python API
`#today <https://blender.chat/channel/to: `#today <https://blender.chat/channel/today>`__ For getting answers from the community
`Blender FAQ <https://www.blender.org/su: `-- Blender FAQ <https://www.blender.org/support/faq/>`__ (Can I use Blender commercially? What is GPL/GNU? ...)
`Blender Publisher <https://download.ble: `-- Blender Publisher <https://download.blender.org/release/Publisher2.25/>`__ becomes freely available, and the experimental tree of Blender is created, a coder's playground

`Installing SVN and Downloading the Repo: `-- Installing SVN and Downloading the Repository`_

``#docs`` channel for informal discussio: ``#docs`` channel for informal discussions in real-time
``:abbr:`SSAO (Screen Space Ambient Occl: ``:abbr:`SSAO (Scree-- Screen Space Ambient Occlusion``` -- Abbreviations display the full text as a tooltip for the reader
``:term:`Manifold``` -- Links to an entr: ``:term:`-- Manifold``` -- Links to an entry in the :doc:`-- Glossary </glossary/index>`
``blender-v{VERSION}-release`` branch: f: ``-- blender-v{VERSION}-release`` branch: fixes and other incremental improvements
``master`` branch: documentation for new: ``-- master`` branch: documentation for new features and improvements for the release after that
``|BLENDER_VERSION|`` -- Resolves to the: ``|BLENDER_VERSION|`` -- Resolves to the current Blender version
ref:`Communicating <contribute-contact>`: ref:`-- Communicating <contribute-contact>` early and frequently is the key to have a productive environment, to not waste people's effort and to attain a better Blender manual as a result
